By predicting the place in the respective trial sequence from which the input window was sampled, EEG-D3 separates latent components of brain activity, akin to non-linear ICA. We utilise a novel model architecture with fully independent sub-networks for strict interpretability. We outline a feature interpretation paradigm to contrast the component activation profiles on different datasets and inspect the associated temporal and spatial filters. The proposed method reliably separates latent components of brain activity on motor imagery data. Training downstream classifiers on an appropriate subset of these components prevents hidden overfitting caused by task-correlated artefacts, which severely affects end-to-end classifiers. We further exploit the linearly separable latent space for effective few-shot learning on sleep stage classification. The ability to distinguish genuine components of brain activity from spurious features results in models that avoid the hidden overfitting problem and generalise well to real-world applications, while requiring only minimal labelled data. With interest to the neuroscience community, the proposed method gives researchers a tool to separate individual brain processes and potentially even uncover heretofore unknown dynamics.

item.title: The Double Life of Code World Models: Provably Unmasking Malicious Behavior Through Execution Traces
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Large Language Models, Code Generation, Backdoor Detection, Semantic Orbit Analysis, Adversarial Robustness Quotient

Summary:

This paper addresses security concerns related to large language models (LLMs) that generate code, focusing on the risk of backdoor injection and malicious outputs. It introduces the Cross-Trace Verification Protocol (CTVP), an innovative AI control framework designed to verify the trustworthiness of untrusted code-generating models. Instead of executing the generated code, which might be harmful, CTVP analyzes the model's predicted execution traces over multiple semantically equivalent program transformations, forming a semantic orbit. By examining the consistency of these predicted execution traces, the protocol can identify behavioral anomalies suggestive of backdoor manipulations. The paper also presents the Adversarial Robustness Quotient (ARQ), a metric quantifying the computational effort of verification relative to normal code generation, which grows exponentially with the size of the semantic orbit. Theoretical information-theoretic analysis reveals that adversaries cannot exploit (or gamify) the protocol through training because of inherent space complexity constraints. Conclusively, the study demonstrates that semantic orbit analysis provides a scalable and theoretically justified approach to monitoring and controlling AI-driven code generation, enhancing the safety and reliability of LLM-generated programs.
arXiv:2512.13821v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large language models (LLMs) increasingly generate code with minimal human oversight, raising critical concerns about backdoor injection and malicious behavior. We present Cross-Trace Verification Protocol (CTVP), a novel AI control framework that verifies untrusted code-generating models through semantic orbit analysis. Rather than directly executing potentially malicious code, CTVP leverages the model's own predictions of execution traces across semantically equivalent program transformations. By analyzing consistency patterns in these predicted traces, we detect behavioral anomalies indicative of backdoors. Our approach introduces the Adversarial Robustness Quotient (ARQ), which quantifies the computational cost of verification relative to baseline generation, demonstrating exponential growth with orbit size. Theoretical analysis establishes information-theoretic bounds showing non-gamifiability -- adversaries cannot improve through training due to fundamental space complexity constraints. This work demonstrates that semantic orbit analysis provides a scalable, theoretically grounded approach to AI control for code generation tasks.

item.title: Explainable reinforcement learning from human feedback to improve alignment
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: reinforcement learning from human feedback, language models, post-hoc explanation, unlearning, data selection

Summary: This paper explores applying a human improvement strategy—identifying causes of unsatisfactory outcomes and correcting them—to enhance reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF) used in aligning language models (LMs). It highlights that despite RLHF tuning, LMs can still generate unsatisfactory responses. To address this, the authors propose a two-part method. First, they develop a post-hoc explanation technique that identifies specific training data causing an unsatisfactory prompt-response output. This is formulated as a constrained combinatorial optimization problem, aiming to find a set of training examples closest to the problematic prompt-response pair in a feature space, with the constraint that the pair can be represented as a convex combination of this set. An efficient iterative data selection algorithm is introduced to solve this problem. Second, the paper presents an unlearning method that removes the influence of identified training data responsible for poor responses, aiming to improve these responses without significantly degrading others that are satisfactory. Experimental results demonstrate that this approach can effectively improve RLHF performance, leading to better alignment and quality of language model outputs.
arXiv:2512.13837v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: A common and effective strategy for humans to improve an unsatisfactory outcome in daily life is to find a cause of this outcome and correct the cause. In this paper, we investigate whether this human improvement strategy can be applied to improving reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF) for alignment of language models (LMs). In particular, it is observed in the literature that LMs tuned by RLHF can still output unsatisfactory responses. This paper proposes a method to improve the unsatisfactory responses by correcting their causes. Our method has two parts. The first part proposes a post-hoc explanation method to explain why an unsatisfactory response is generated to a prompt by identifying the training data that lead to this response. We formulate this problem as a constrained combinatorial optimization problem where the objective is to find a set of training data closest to this prompt-response pair in a feature representation space, and the constraint is that the prompt-response pair can be decomposed as a convex combination of this set of training data in the feature space. We propose an efficient iterative data selection algorithm to solve this problem. The second part proposes an unlearning method that improves unsatisfactory responses to some prompts by unlearning the training data that lead to these unsatisfactory responses and, meanwhile, does not significantly degrade satisfactory responses to other prompts. Experimental results demonstrate that our algorithm can improve RLHF.

item.title: Topologically-Stabilized Graph Neural Networks: Empirical Robustness Across Domains
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Graph Neural Networks, Persistent Homology, Stability Regularization, Robustness, Topological Features

Summary:

1. This paper addresses the vulnerability of Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) to structural perturbations by proposing a new framework that integrates persistent homology features with stability regularization.
2. The approach builds upon the stability theorems of persistent homology and combines Graph Isomorphism Network (GIN) architectures with multi-scale topological features derived from persistence images.
3. Stability constraints inspired by Hiraoka-Kusano theory are used to enforce robustness during learning, linking recent advances in topological regularization to GNN design.
4. Experimental evaluation on six diverse datasets, including biochemical, social, and collaboration networks, demonstrates that the proposed method significantly improves robustness to edge perturbations while maintaining competitive accuracy.
5. Results show minimal performance degradation (0-4% on most datasets) under perturbations, outperforming baseline models and providing a theoretically grounded and empirically validated approach to robust graph learning through topological techniques.
arXiv:2512.13852v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have become the standard for graph representation learning but remain vulnerable to structural perturbations. We propose a novel framework that integrates persistent homology features with stability regularization to enhance robustness. Building on the stability theorems of persistent homology \cite{cohen2007stability}, our method combines GIN architectures with multi-scale topological features extracted from persistence images, enforced by Hiraoka-Kusano-inspired stability constraints. Across six diverse datasets spanning biochemical, social, and collaboration networks , our approach demonstrates exceptional robustness to edge perturbations while maintaining competitive accuracy. Notably, we observe minimal performance degradation (0-4\% on most datasets) under perturbation, significantly outperforming baseline stability. Our work provides both a theoretically-grounded and empirically-validated approach to robust graph learning that aligns with recent advances in topological regularization

item.title: Dropout Neural Network Training Viewed from a Percolation Perspective
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: percolation, dropout, neural networks, stochastic gradient descent, network topology

Summary: This work explores the concept of percolation within the context of training deep neural networks (NNs) using dropout, a technique that randomly removes connections during training to regularize the model. The authors draw an analogy between the random removal of connections in dropout and percolation, a well-studied model in statistical physics. They specifically investigate whether dropout can remove enough connections to sever the path between the input and output layers of the NN, which would prevent the model from making informed predictions. To analyze this, new percolation models are proposed that mimic the dropout process on neural network topologies. Their theoretical findings confirm the existence of a percolative effect in dropout, showing that the network's underlying topology plays a crucial role in maintaining connectivity during training. Furthermore, they demonstrate that in the absence of bias terms, this percolative effect can cause a breakdown in training, where the network fails to learn effectively. The authors also provide heuristic arguments suggesting that this detrimental effect extends to networks with biases as well, highlighting important considerations for the design and training of dropout-enabled neural networks.
arXiv:2512.13853v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: In this work, we investigate the existence and effect of percolation in training deep Neural Networks (NNs) with dropout. Dropout methods are regularisation techniques for training NNs, first introduced by G. Hinton et al. (2012). These methods temporarily remove connections in the NN, randomly at each stage of training, and update the remaining subnetwork with Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD). The process of removing connections from a network at random is similar to percolation, a paradigm model of statistical physics. If dropout were to remove enough connections such that there is no path between the input and output of the NN, then the NN could not make predictions informed by the data. We study new percolation models that mimic dropout in NNs and characterise the relationship between network topology and this path problem. The theory shows the existence of a percolative effect in dropout. We also show that this percolative effect can cause a breakdown when training NNs without biases with dropout; and we argue heuristically that this breakdown extends to NNs with biases.

item.title: Measuring Uncertainty Calibration
item.content:encoded:
Calibration, binary classifier, L1 error, bounded variation, non-asymptotic

Summary:

This article addresses the challenge of estimating the $L_1$ calibration error of binary classifiers using finite datasets. First, it establishes an upper bound on this calibration error for classifiers whose calibration functions have bounded variation, providing a theoretical guarantee that can be applied broadly. Second, the authors introduce a novel method to modify any given classifier in a way that enables efficient upper bounding of its calibration error. This modification does not significantly degrade the classifier’s predictive performance and does not rely on restrictive assumptions, making it widely applicable. Importantly, all results presented are non-asymptotic, meaning they hold for finite samples, and distribution-free, so they do not depend on specific data distribution characteristics. Finally, the paper offers practical guidance on how to measure calibration error in real-world settings, emphasizing procedures that can be implemented with modest computational overhead. These contributions collectively offer both theoretical insights and practical tools for better assessing and improving the calibration of binary classifiers in applied machine learning contexts.
arXiv:2512.13872v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We make two contributions to the problem of estimating the $L_1$ calibration error of a binary classifier from a finite dataset. First, we provide an upper bound for any classifier where the calibration function has bounded variation. Second, we provide a method of modifying any classifier so that its calibration error can be upper bounded efficiently without significantly impacting classifier performance and without any restrictive assumptions. All our results are non-asymptotic and distribution-free. We conclude by providing advice on how to measure calibration error in practice. Our methods yield practical procedures that can be run on real-world datasets with modest overhead.

item.title: Privacy-Enhancing Infant Cry Classification with Federated Transformers and Denoising Regularization
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: infant cry classification, federated learning, denoising autoencoder, noise robustness, privacy-preserving

Summary: This paper addresses the challenge of infant cry classification, which is crucial for early assessment of infant needs but hindered by privacy concerns, background noise, and domain shifts in recording environments. The authors propose an end-to-end pipeline combining a denoising autoencoder (DAE), a convolutional tokenizer, and a Transformer encoder, designed to work efficiently on-device. The system incorporates adaptive segmentation, post hoc calibration, and energy-based out-of-distribution (OOD) abstention to improve robustness and reliability. Federated learning (FL) is utilized to preserve privacy by training models across devices without sharing raw data, employing a communication-efficient method using regularized control variate updates and 8-bit adapter deltas under secure aggregation. Experiments conducted on the Baby Chillanto and Donate-a-Cry datasets with added ESC-50 noise overlays show a strong classification performance with a macro F1 score of 0.938, AUC of 0.962, and low Expected Calibration Error (ECE) of 0.032. The approach significantly reduces communication overhead, cutting client upload size per round from about 36–42 MB down to 3.3 MB. Additionally, real-time inference on an NVIDIA Jetson Nano edge device requires only 96 ms per one-second spectrogram frame. These advancements highlight a viable, privacy-conscious, noise-robust, and communication-efficient solution for infant cry classification suitable for federated deployment scenarios.
arXiv:2512.13880v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Infant cry classification can aid early assessment of infant needs. However, deployment of such solutions is limited by privacy concerns around audio data, sensitivity to background noise, and domain shift across recording environments. We present an end-to-end infant cry analysis pipeline that integrates a denoising autoencoder (DAE), a convolutional tokenizer, and a Transformer encoder trained using communication-efficient federated learning (FL). The system performs on-device denoising, adaptive segmentation, post hoc calibration, and energy-based out-of-distribution (OOD) abstention. Federated training employs a regularized control variate update with 8-bit adapter deltas under secure aggregation. Using the Baby Chillanto and Donate-a-Cry datasets with ESC-50 noise overlays, the model achieves a macro F1 score of 0.938, an AUC of 0.962, and an Expected Calibration Error (ECE) of 0.032, while reducing per-round client upload from approximately 36 to 42 MB to 3.3 MB. Real-time edge inference on an NVIDIA Jetson Nano (4 GB, TensorRT FP16) achieves 96 ms per one-second spectrogram frame. These results demonstrate a practical path toward privacy-preserving, noise-robust, and communication-efficient infant cry classification suitable for federated deployment.

item.title: OPTIMA: Optimal One-shot Pruning for LLMs via Quadratic Programming Reconstruction
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: post-training pruning, OPTIMA, quadratic programming, large language models, model compression

Summary: 1. Post-training model pruning balances the trade-off between fast, simple heuristics that degrade accuracy and computationally infeasible joint optimization methods that maintain accuracy. 2. One-shot methods like SparseGPT provide a practical middle ground by applying efficient approximate heuristic weight updates but still leave room for improvement in accuracy and scalability. 3. OPTIMA is introduced as a novel one-shot post-training pruning method that achieves a better balance of accuracy and scalability by formulating layer-wise weight reconstruction after mask selection as independent, row-wise Quadratic Programs (QPs) sharing a common Hessian matrix per layer. 4. The shared-Hessian structure allows batching on hardware accelerators, and a custom accelerator-friendly QP solver solves many small QPs in parallel, enabling large-scale pruning on a single accelerator without requiring fine-tuning. 5. OPTIMA integrates with existing mask selectors, consistently improving zero-shot model performance by up to 3.97% absolute accuracy across multiple large language model families and sparsity levels. On an NVIDIA H100 accelerator, OPTIMA prunes an 8-billion-parameter transformer model end-to-end in 40 hours using 60GB peak memory, setting a new state-of-the-art in accuracy-efficiency trade-offs for one-shot post-training pruning.
arXiv:2512.13886v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Post-training model pruning is a promising solution, yet it faces a trade-off: simple heuristics that zero weights are fast but degrade accuracy, while principled joint optimization methods recover accuracy but are computationally infeasible at modern scale. One-shot methods such as SparseGPT offer a practical trade-off in optimality by applying efficient, approximate heuristic weight updates. To close this gap, we introduce OPTIMA, a practical one-shot post-training pruning method that balances accuracy and scalability. OPTIMA casts layer-wise weight reconstruction after mask selection as independent, row-wise Quadratic Programs (QPs) that share a common layer Hessian. Solving these QPs yields the per-row globally optimal update with respect to the reconstruction objective given the estimated Hessian. The shared-Hessian structure makes the problem highly amenable to batching on accelerators. We implement an accelerator-friendly QP solver that accumulates one Hessian per layer and solves many small QPs in parallel, enabling one-shot post-training pruning at scale on a single accelerator without fine-tuning. OPTIMA integrates with existing mask selectors and consistently improves zero-shot performance across multiple LLM families and sparsity regimes, yielding up to 3.97% absolute accuracy improvement. On an NVIDIA H100, OPTIMA prunes a 8B-parameter transformer end-to-end in 40 hours with 60GB peak memory. Together, these results set a new state-of-the-art accuracy-efficiency trade-offs for one-shot post-training pruning.

item.title: Let's (not) just put things in Context: Test-Time Training for Long-Context LLMs
item.content:encoded:
Long-context, inference-time compute, static self-attention, score dilution, gradient updates

Summary: 1. Large language models (LLMs) have achieved the ability to process millions of tokens in context, but their effective use of extremely long contexts remains limited. 2. Current inference-time compute strategies, such as generating additional "thinking tokens" for complex multi-step reasoning tasks, show diminishing returns and fail when applied to long-context scenarios. 3. The root cause of these failures is identified as "score dilution," an issue intrinsic to the static self-attention mechanism used in most LLM architectures, which hampers the retrieval of relevant signals from long contexts. 4. The paper proposes a novel approach involving targeted gradient updates on the input context during inference; this method overcomes the limitations of static self-attention and enhances the model’s ability to use long contexts. 5. Experimental results demonstrate substantial performance improvements, with increases of 12.6 and 14.1 percentage points on subsets of LongBench-v2 and ZeroScrolls benchmarks for the Qwen3-4B model, showing that context-specific training at inference is more effective than merely scaling inference-time compute by generating more tokens. 6. The practical takeaway is that investing a small amount of inference-time compute in context-specific gradient updates yields better long-context performance than existing strategies focused on scaling token generation.
arXiv:2512.13898v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Progress on training and architecture strategies has enabled LLMs with millions of tokens in context length. However, empirical evidence suggests that such long-context LLMs can consume far more text than they can reliably use. On the other hand, it has been shown that inference-time compute can be used to scale performance of LLMs, often by generating thinking tokens, on challenging tasks involving multi-step reasoning. Through controlled experiments on sandbox long-context tasks, we find that such inference-time strategies show rapidly diminishing returns and fail at long context. We attribute these failures to score dilution, a phenomenon inherent to static self-attention. Further, we show that current inference-time strategies cannot retrieve relevant long-context signals under certain conditions. We propose a simple method that, through targeted gradient updates on the given context, provably overcomes limitations of static self-attention. We find that this shift in how inference-time compute is spent leads to consistently large performance improvements across models and long-context benchmarks. Our method leads to large 12.6 and 14.1 percentage point improvements for Qwen3-4B on average across subsets of LongBench-v2 and ZeroScrolls benchmarks. The takeaway is practical: for long context, a small amount of context-specific training is a better use of inference compute than current inference-time scaling strategies like producing more thinking tokens.

item.title: Exploring Machine Learning, Deep Learning, and Explainable AI Methods for Seasonal Precipitation Prediction in South America
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: precipitation forecasting, machine learning, deep learning, South America, explainable AI

Summary: 1. Forecasting meteorological variables like precipitation is difficult due to their complex nature, yet accurate predictions are crucial for mitigating climate-related impacts on society. 2. This study evaluates purely data-driven approaches for precipitation forecasting across all seasons of 2019 in South America, comparing classical machine learning (Random Forests, XGBoost) and deep learning methods (1D CNN, LSTM, GRU). 3. The Brazilian Global Atmospheric Model (BAM) serves as a benchmark representing traditional dynamic modeling. 4. Explainable artificial intelligence (XAI) techniques were applied to interpret model behavior and improve understanding of results. 5. Among the models tested, the LSTM deep learning model achieved the best predictive performance, particularly excelling in forecasting heavy precipitation events, despite having higher computational latency. 6. XGBoost offered a good trade-off with lower latency and only a slight reduction in accuracy, making it a suitable option when computational cost is a concern. 7. BAM, the traditional dynamic model, performed the worst in forecasting accuracy in this study. 8. The results support the feasibility and effectiveness of deep learning models in climate and meteorological forecasting, aligning with global trends in meteorological research and operational centers.
arXiv:2512.13910v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Forecasting meteorological variables is challenging due to the complexity of their processes, requiring advanced models for accuracy. Accurate precipitation forecasts are vital for society. Reliable predictions help communities mitigate climatic impacts. Based on the current relevance of artificial intelligence (AI), classical machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) techniques have been used as an alternative or complement to dynamic modeling. However, there is still a lack of broad investigations into the feasibility of purely data-driven approaches for precipitation forecasting. This study aims at addressing this issue where different classical ML and DL approaches for forecasting precipitation in South America, taking into account all 2019 seasons, are considered in a detailed investigation. The selected classical ML techniques were Random Forests and extreme gradient boosting (XGBoost), while the DL counterparts were a 1D convolutional neural network (CNN 1D), a long short-term memory (LSTM) model, and a gated recurrent unit (GRU) model. Additionally, the Brazilian Global Atmospheric Model (BAM) was used as a representative of the traditional dynamic modeling approach. We also relied on explainable artificial intelligence (XAI) to provide some explanations for the models behaviors. LSTM showed strong predictive performance while BAM, the traditional dynamic model representative, had the worst results. Despite presented the higher latency, LSTM was most accurate for heavy precipitation. If cost is a concern, XGBoost offers lower latency with slightly accuracy loss. The results of this research confirm the viability of DL models for climate forecasting, solidifying a global trend in major meteorological and climate forecasting centers.

item.title: Capturing reduced-order quantum many-body dynamics out of equilibrium via neural ordinary differential equations
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: quantum many-body systems, two-particle reduced density matrix, neural ODE, three-particle cumulant, memory effects

Summary:

1. Out-of-equilibrium quantum many-body systems develop rapid correlation buildup critical to emergent phenomena, but exact wave-function methods scale exponentially with particle number, and mean-field approaches miss essential two-particle correlations.

2. The time-dependent two-particle reduced density matrix (TD2RDM) formalism provides a compromise by evolving the 2RDM and approximating the three-particle cumulant to close the BBGKY hierarchy.

3. It remains uncertain whether time-local reconstruction functionals that ignore memory effects can effectively describe dynamics across different regimes.

4. Using a neural ordinary differential equation (neural ODE) trained on exact 2RDM data, the study demonstrates that the dynamics can be reproduced without explicit three-particle information only when the two- and three-particle cumulants are strongly correlated.

5. In regimes where these cumulants are anti-correlated or uncorrelated, the neural ODE fails, indicating the necessity for memory-dependent kernels in three-particle cumulant reconstruction.

6. The magnitude of time-averaged three-particle correlation buildup predicts the success of both neural ODE and existing TD2RDM reconstructions; moderate buildup yields accurate predictions while strong buildup causes systematic failure.

7. The neural ODE thus serves as a model-agnostic diagnostic tool to identify suitable regimes for cumulant expansion methods and to guide development of non-local closure schemes.

8. More generally, this approach offers a pathway for fast, data-driven simulations of correlated quantum matter by learning high-dimensional reduced density matrix dynamics with limited data.
arXiv:2512.13913v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Out-of-equilibrium quantum many-body systems exhibit rapid correlation buildup that underlies many emerging phenomena. Exact wave-function methods to describe this scale exponentially with particle number; simpler mean-field approaches neglect essential two-particle correlations. The time-dependent two-particle reduced density matrix (TD2RDM) formalism offers a middle ground by propagating the two-particle reduced density matrix (2RDM) and closing the BBGKY hierarchy with a reconstruction of the three-particle cumulant. But the validity and existence of time-local reconstruction functionals ignoring memory effects remain unclear across different dynamical regimes. We show that a neural ODE model trained on exact 2RDM data (no dimensionality reduction) can reproduce its dynamics without any explicit three-particle information -- but only in parameter regions where the Pearson correlation between the two- and three-particle cumulants is large. In the anti-correlated or uncorrelated regime, the neural ODE fails, indicating that no simple time-local functional of the instantaneous two-particle cumulant can capture the evolution. The magnitude of the time-averaged three-particle-correlation buildup appears to be the primary predictor of success: For a moderate correlation buildup, both neural ODE predictions and existing TD2RDM reconstructions are accurate, whereas stronger values lead to systematic breakdowns. These findings pinpoint the need for memory-dependent kernels in the three-particle cumulant reconstruction for the latter regime. Our results place the neural ODE as a model-agnostic diagnostic tool that maps the regime of applicability of cumulant expansion methods and guides the development of non-local closure schemes. More broadly, the ability to learn high-dimensional RDM dynamics from limited data opens a pathway to fast, data-driven simulation of correlated quantum matter.

item.title: Adaptive digital twins for predictive decision-making: Online Bayesian learning of transition dynamics
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: adaptive digital twins, probabilistic graphical models, dynamic Bayesian networks, reinforcement learning, structural health monitoring

Summary:

This work demonstrates how adaptivity improves the value realization of digital twins in civil engineering by focusing on adaptive state transition models within digital twins. These digital twins are represented via probabilistic graphical models, specifically dynamic Bayesian networks that capture bi-directional interactions between physical and virtual domains. The method treats state transition probabilities as random variables with conjugate priors, facilitating hierarchical online learning of system dynamics through Bayesian updates. The authors extend the mathematical framework to cover a broader class of distributions than prior literature. For policy computation with precision updates, parametric Markov decision processes are solved using reinforcement learning techniques. This adaptive digital twin approach results in enhanced personalization, increased system robustness, and better cost-effectiveness in maintenance operations. The framework is validated through a case study focused on structural health monitoring and maintenance planning for a railway bridge, demonstrating practical benefits in civil engineering asset management.
arXiv:2512.13919v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: This work shows how adaptivity can enhance value realization of digital twins in civil engineering. We focus on adapting the state transition models within digital twins represented through probabilistic graphical models. The bi-directional interaction between the physical and virtual domains is modeled using dynamic Bayesian networks. By treating state transition probabilities as random variables endowed with conjugate priors, we enable hierarchical online learning of transition dynamics from a state to another through effortless Bayesian updates. We provide the mathematical framework to account for a larger class of distributions with respect to the current literature. To compute dynamic policies with precision updates we solve parametric Markov decision processes through reinforcement learning. The proposed adaptive digital twin framework enjoys enhanced personalization, increased robustness, and improved cost-effectiveness. We assess our approach on a case study involving structural health monitoring and maintenance planning of a railway bridge.

item.title: Sliding Window Recurrences for Sequence Models
item.content:encoded:
Multi-hybrid architectures, hierarchical decomposition, Sliding Window Recurrences, Phalanx layers, GPU memory optimization

Summary: This paper introduces a hierarchical decomposition framework for linear recurrences designed to optimize language model performance by better aligning computations with GPU memory hierarchies. The approach leads to the creation of Sliding Window Recurrences (SWR), which focus specifically on truncating recurrences into hardware-aligned windows. These windows are jagged in shape, which naturally limits the expensive communication between GPU warps, thereby improving computational efficiency. Utilizing SWR, the authors develop Phalanx layers that can replace traditional windowed attention mechanisms or linear recurrence layers seamlessly. In large-scale multi-hybrid language models with 1 billion parameters, integrating Phalanx layers results in significant speed improvements, achieving a 10-40% increase in processing speed across varied context lengths from 4,000 to 32,000 tokens. Importantly, these performance gains do not come at the cost of model quality, as the perplexity remains comparable to that of state-of-the-art optimized Transformer models. Overall, the work presents a scalable and hardware-aware solution for enhancing both the efficiency and quality of long-context language models.
arXiv:2512.13921v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Multi-hybrid architectures are poised to take over language modeling due to better quality and performance. We introduce a hierarchical decomposition framework for linear recurrences that allows us to develop algorithms aligned with GPU memory hierarchies, yielding Sliding Window Recurrences. We focus specifically on truncating recurrences to hardware-aligned windows which are naturally jagged, limiting costly inter-warp communication. Using SWR, we develop Phalanx layers that serve as drop-in replacements for windowed attention or linear recurrences. In 1B parameter multi-hybrid models, Phalanx achieves over 10-40% speedup across 4K to 32K context length over optimized Transformers while matching perplexity.

item.title: A Complete Guide to Spherical Equivariant Graph Transformers
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: spherical equivariant graph neural networks, SO(3) group, molecular modeling, tensor field networks, equivariant message-passing

Summary: This article presents a comprehensive and intuitive guide to spherical equivariant graph neural networks (EGNNs), which are designed to handle 3D molecular and biomolecular data while respecting rotational symmetries dictated by physics. It begins by establishing foundational concepts including group representations, spherical harmonics, tensor products, and the Clebsch-Gordan decomposition, which are essential for constructing SO(3)-equivariant kernels. These kernels ensure that neural network predictions transform correctly under rotations, maintaining physical relevance. Building on this theoretical groundwork, the authors develop and discuss the Tensor Field Network and SE(3)-Transformer architectures, which extend traditional message-passing graph neural networks and Transformers by encoding features as spherical tensors. The paper explains how these architectures perform equivariant message-passing and attention mechanisms on geometric graphs, enabling effective learning of molecular structures. Additionally, the guide includes detailed mathematical derivations and annotated code snippets to facilitate understanding and implementation. The intended audience includes researchers and practitioners interested in applying spherical EGNNs to chemistry-related domains such as molecular property prediction, protein structure modeling, and generative modeling. This work provides a self-contained resource to bridge theoretical concepts with practical network architectures for equivariant learning on 3D molecular data.
arXiv:2512.13927v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Spherical equivariant graph neural networks (EGNNs) provide a principled framework for learning on three-dimensional molecular and biomolecular systems, where predictions must respect the rotational symmetries inherent in physics. These models extend traditional message-passing GNNs and Transformers by representing node and edge features as spherical tensors that transform under irreducible representations of the rotation group SO(3), ensuring that predictions change in physically meaningful ways under rotations of the input. This guide develops a complete, intuitive foundation for spherical equivariant modeling - from group representations and spherical harmonics, to tensor products, Clebsch-Gordan decomposition, and the construction of SO(3)-equivariant kernels. Building on this foundation, we construct the Tensor Field Network and SE(3)-Transformer architectures and explain how they perform equivariant message-passing and attention on geometric graphs. Through clear mathematical derivations and annotated code excerpts, this guide serves as a self-contained introduction for researchers and learners seeking to understand or implement spherical EGNNs for applications in chemistry, molecular property prediction, protein structure modeling, and generative modeling.

item.title: Informing Acquisition Functions via Foundation Models for Molecular Discovery
item.content:encoded:
Bayesian Optimization, Large Language Models, Molecular Discovery, Monte Carlo Tree Search, Surrogate Modeling

Summary:

This paper addresses the challenges of Bayesian Optimization (BO) in molecular discovery, particularly in low-data regimes with vast candidate spaces and limited prior knowledge. Traditional BO relies on probabilistic surrogate models to map molecules to properties and optimize acquisition functions, but faces limitations due to high-dimensional features and the computational cost of deep Bayesian surrogates. To overcome these issues, the authors propose a likelihood-free BO approach that eliminates explicit surrogate modeling and directly leverages priors from both general large language models (LLMs) and chemistry-specific foundation models to guide acquisition function estimation. Their method incorporates a tree-structured partitioning of the molecular search space, applying local acquisition functions within each partition, and uses Monte Carlo Tree Search (MCTS) to efficiently navigate candidate selections. Additionally, the method employs coarse-grained LLM-based clustering to focus acquisition function evaluations on clusters with statistically higher property values, improving scalability to large candidate sets. Extensive experiments and ablation studies demonstrate that this approach significantly enhances scalability, robustness, and sample efficiency in LLM-guided Bayesian Optimization for molecular discovery tasks.
arXiv:2512.13935v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Bayesian Optimization (BO) is a key methodology for accelerating molecular discovery by estimating the mapping from molecules to their properties while seeking the optimal candidate. Typically, BO iteratively updates a probabilistic surrogate model of this mapping and optimizes acquisition functions derived from the model to guide molecule selection. However, its performance is limited in low-data regimes with insufficient prior knowledge and vast candidate spaces. Large language models (LLMs) and chemistry foundation models offer rich priors to enhance BO, but high-dimensional features, costly in-context learning, and the computational burden of deep Bayesian surrogates hinder their full utilization. To address these challenges, we propose a likelihood-free BO method that bypasses explicit surrogate modeling and directly leverages priors from general LLMs and chemistry-specific foundation models to inform acquisition functions. Our method also learns a tree-structured partition of the molecular search space with local acquisition functions, enabling efficient candidate selection via Monte Carlo Tree Search. By further incorporating coarse-grained LLM-based clustering, it substantially improves scalability to large candidate sets by restricting acquisition function evaluations to clusters with statistically higher property values. We show through extensive experiments and ablations that the proposed method substantially improves scalability, robustness, and sample efficiency in LLM-guided BO for molecular discovery.

item.title: Pattern-Guided Diffusion Models
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Diffusion models, pattern-guided forecasting, archetypal analysis, uncertainty quantification, multivariate time series

Summary:

1. The paper introduces Pattern-Guided Diffusion Models (PGDM), a novel approach for forecasting future data in multivariate time series by leveraging recurring patterns inherent in the data.

2. PGDM utilizes archetypal analysis to extract patterns and predict the most likely next pattern in the temporal sequence, which guides the diffusion model’s forecasting process.

3. This pattern-guided approach helps produce more realistic and plausible future predictions that conform to known temporal structures.

4. The authors propose a new uncertainty quantification method based on archetypal analysis, allowing dynamic adjustment of the guidance strength depending on the uncertainty of the pattern estimate.

5. The method was evaluated on two applications: predicting visual field measurements and motion capture frames, where PGDM showed significant improvement over baselines.

6. Quantitative results demonstrate that pattern guidance enhanced performance metrics such as Mean Absolute Error (MAE) and Continuous Ranked Probability Score (CRPS) by up to 40.67% / 56.26% and 14.12% / 14.10% for the two tasks respectively.

7. When compared to baseline methods, PGDM outperformed them by large margins, up to 65.58% / 84.83% and 93.64% / 92.55%, showing the strength of leveraging inherent patterns in time series forecasting.
arXiv:2512.13945v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Diffusion models have shown promise in forecasting future data from multivariate time series. However, few existing methods account for recurring structures, or patterns, that appear within the data. We present Pattern-Guided Diffusion Models (PGDM), which leverage inherent patterns within temporal data for forecasting future time steps. PGDM first extracts patterns using archetypal analysis and estimates the most likely next pattern in the sequence. By guiding predictions with this pattern estimate, PGDM makes more realistic predictions that fit within the set of known patterns. We additionally introduce a novel uncertainty quantification technique based on archetypal analysis, and we dynamically scale the guidance level based on the pattern estimate uncertainty. We apply our method to two well-motivated forecasting applications, predicting visual field measurements and motion capture frames. On both, we show that pattern guidance improves PGDM's performance (MAE / CRPS) by up to 40.67% / 56.26% and 14.12% / 14.10%, respectively. PGDM also outperforms baselines by up to 65.58% / 84.83% and 93.64% / 92.55%.

item.title: A Single Architecture for Representing Invariance Under Any Space Group
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: space groups, machine learning, symmetry invariance, Fourier bases, zero-shot learning

Summary: This work addresses the challenge of incorporating crystallographic symmetries, specifically the 230 three-dimensional space groups, into machine learning models for materials science and condensed matter physics. Traditionally, achieving exact invariance to these symmetries requires specialized architectures designed for each group, limiting scalability and knowledge transfer. The authors propose a novel approach that constructs symmetry-adapted Fourier bases by explicitly characterizing the constraints that group operations impose on Fourier coefficients. These constraints are encoded into a neural network layer, enabling automatic adaptation of weights to enforce invariance across any input space group. This weight-sharing mechanism allows the model to leverage structural similarities among different space groups, overcoming issues related to data sparsity when measurements are limited for specific groups. The approach facilitates zero-shot learning, enabling generalization to unseen space groups without retraining. Experiments demonstrate competitive performance on material property prediction tasks, showcasing the practical application and effectiveness of the method. This unified architecture thus significantly advances the scalability and transferability of symmetry-based machine learning models in materials science.
arXiv:2512.13989v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Incorporating known symmetries in data into machine learning models has consistently improved predictive accuracy, robustness, and generalization. However, achieving exact invariance to specific symmetries typically requires designing bespoke architectures for each group of symmetries, limiting scalability and preventing knowledge transfer across related symmetries. In the case of the space groups, symmetries critical to modeling crystalline solids in materials science and condensed matter physics, this challenge is particularly salient as there are 230 such groups in three dimensions. In this work we present a new approach to such crystallographic symmetries by developing a single machine learning architecture that is capable of adapting its weights automatically to enforce invariance to any input space group. Our approach is based on constructing symmetry-adapted Fourier bases through an explicit characterization of constraints that group operations impose on Fourier coefficients. Encoding these constraints into a neural network layer enables weight sharing across different space groups, allowing the model to leverage structural similarities between groups and overcome data sparsity when limited measurements are available for specific groups. We demonstrate the effectiveness of this approach in achieving competitive performance on material property prediction tasks and performing zero-shot learning to generalize to unseen groups.

item.title: Accelerating MHC-II Epitope Discovery via Multi-Scale Prediction in Antigen Presentation
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: MHC-II, antigenic epitope, immunotherapy, machine learning, peptide presentation

Summary:

This paper addresses the challenges in studying antigenic epitopes presented by MHC-II proteins, which are more complex and less understood compared to MHC-I. It highlights the limitations of existing MHC-II datasets, which are smaller and less standardized, impeding computational immunotherapy research. To overcome these issues, the authors present a well-curated dataset compiled from the Immune Epitope Database (IEDB) and other public sources, extending and standardizing peptide-MHC-II data while introducing a novel antigen-MHC-II dataset enriched with biological context. Using this dataset, they define three machine learning tasks—peptide binding, peptide presentation, and antigen presentation—that model progressively broader biological processes involved in MHC-II antigen presentation. The study also proposes a multi-scale evaluation framework to benchmark current models and undertakes a detailed analysis of different modeling approaches within a modular framework. Overall, this work provides a significant resource for advancing computational immunotherapy by facilitating ML-guided epitope discovery and improving predictive modeling of immune responses, potentially accelerating future research and applications in immunotherapy.
arXiv:2512.14011v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Antigenic epitope presented by major histocompatibility complex II (MHC-II) proteins plays an essential role in immunotherapy. However, compared to the more widely studied MHC-I in computational immunotherapy, the study of MHC-II antigenic epitope poses significantly more challenges due to its complex binding specificity and ambiguous motif patterns. Consequently, existing datasets for MHC-II interactions are smaller and less standardized than those available for MHC-I. To address these challenges, we present a well-curated dataset derived from the Immune Epitope Database (IEDB) and other public sources. It not only extends and standardizes existing peptide-MHC-II datasets, but also introduces a novel antigen-MHC-II dataset with richer biological context. Leveraging this dataset, we formulate three major machine learning (ML) tasks of peptide binding, peptide presentation, and antigen presentation, which progressively capture the broader biological processes within the MHC-II antigen presentation pathway. We further employ a multi-scale evaluation framework to benchmark existing models, along with a comprehensive analysis over various modeling designs to this problem with a modular framework. Overall, this work serves as a valuable resource for advancing computational immunotherapy, providing a foundation for future research in ML guided epitope discovery and predictive modeling of immune responses.

item.title: EXAONE Path 2.5: Pathology Foundation Model with Multi-Omics Alignment
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: multimodal learning, pathology foundation model, cancer progression, contrastive learning, precision oncology

Summary:
1. The article introduces EXAONE Path 2.5, a pathology foundation model designed to integrate multiple biological data layers, including histologic, genomic, epigenetic, and transcriptomic information, aiming to provide a comprehensive representation of tumor biology beyond image-only models.
2. Three main components drive the model: a multimodal SigLIP loss that enables all-pairwise contrastive learning across different types of data modalities; a fragment-aware rotary positional encoding (F-RoPE) module that preserves spatial and tissue-fragment structural information in whole slide images (WSI); and domain-specialized internal foundation models for WSI and RNA-seq that produce biologically meaningful embeddings to improve multimodal alignment.
3. The model was evaluated against six leading pathology foundation models using two benchmarks: an internal real-world clinical dataset and the Patho-Bench benchmark containing 80 diverse tasks.
4. Results show that EXAONE Path 2.5 achieves comparable performance to state-of-the-art models on Patho-Bench while demonstrating superior adaptability and parameter/data efficiency within clinical settings.
5. The study emphasizes the importance of biologically informed multimodal modeling and showcases the potential of integrated genotype-to-phenotype frameworks to advance precision oncology for better cancer progression understanding and clinical application.
arXiv:2512.14019v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Cancer progression arises from interactions across multiple biological layers, especially beyond morphological and across molecular layers that remain invisible to image-only models. To capture this broader biological landscape, we present EXAONE Path 2.5, a pathology foundation model that jointly models histologic, genomic, epigenetic and transcriptomic modalities, producing an integrated patient representation that reflects tumor biology more comprehensively. Our approach incorporates three key components: (1) multimodal SigLIP loss enabling all-pairwise contrastive learning across heterogeneous modalities, (2) a fragment-aware rotary positional encoding (F-RoPE) module that preserves spatial structure and tissue-fragment topology in WSI, and (3) domain-specialized internal foundation models for both WSI and RNA-seq to provide biologically grounded embeddings for robust multimodal alignment. We evaluate EXAONE Path 2.5 against six leading pathology foundation models across two complementary benchmarks: an internal real-world clinical dataset and the Patho-Bench benchmark covering 80 tasks. Our framework demonstrates high data and parameter efficiency, achieving on-par performance with state-of-the-art foundation models on Patho-Bench while exhibiting the highest adaptability in the internal clinical setting. These results highlight the value of biologically informed multimodal design and underscore the potential of integrated genotype-to-phenotype modeling for next-generation precision oncology.

item.title: Multivariate Time Series Forecasting with Hybrid Euclidean-SPD Manifold Graph Neural Networks
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Multivariate Time Series, Hybrid Geometric Representation, Graph Neural Network, Riemannian Manifold, Forecasting Accuracy

Summary: Multivariate Time Series (MTS) forecasting is crucial for applications like traffic management and predictive maintenance. Traditional methods focus on modeling MTS in either Euclidean or Riemannian space, which restricts their ability to fully capture the complex geometric structures and spatio-temporal dependencies in real-world data. This work introduces the Hybrid Symmetric Positive-Definite Manifold Graph Neural Network (HSMGNN), a novel model that combines Euclidean and Riemannian geometric representations within a graph neural network framework to enhance expressiveness and comprehensiveness. A key innovation is the Submanifold-Cross-Segment (SCS) embedding, projecting MTS data into both geometric spaces to better capture spatio-temporal variations across domains. To address the heavy computational demands of calculating Riemannian distances, the model includes an Adaptive-Distance-Bank (ADB) layer equipped with a trainable memory mechanism for efficiency. The learned dual-space features are then fused using a Fusion Graph Convolutional Network (FGCN) with a trainable fusion operator to improve prediction accuracy. Experimental results on three benchmark datasets demonstrate that HSMGNN outperforms current state-of-the-art models, achieving up to a 13.8% improvement in forecasting accuracy. This work represents the first use of hybrid geometric frameworks for MTS forecasting, offering a promising direction for future research.
arXiv:2512.14023v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Multivariate Time Series (MTS) forecasting plays a vital role in various real-world applications, such as traffic management and predictive maintenance. Existing approaches typically model MTS data in either Euclidean or Riemannian space, limiting their ability to capture the diverse geometric structures and complex spatio-temporal dependencies inherent in real-world data. To overcome this limitation, we propose the Hybrid Symmetric Positive-Definite Manifold Graph Neural Network (HSMGNN), a novel graph neural network-based model that captures data geometry within a hybrid Euclidean-Riemannian framework. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first work to leverage hybrid geometric representations for MTS forecasting, enabling expressive and comprehensive modeling of geometric properties. Specifically, we introduce a Submanifold-Cross-Segment (SCS) embedding to project input MTS into both Euclidean and Riemannian spaces, thereby capturing spatio-temporal variations across distinct geometric domains. To alleviate the high computational cost of Riemannian distance, we further design an Adaptive-Distance-Bank (ADB) layer with a trainable memory mechanism. Finally, a Fusion Graph Convolutional Network (FGCN) is devised to integrate features from the dual spaces via a learnable fusion operator for accurate prediction. Experiments on three benchmark datasets demonstrate that HSMGNN achieves up to a 13.8 percent improvement over state-of-the-art baselines in forecasting accuracy.

item.title: FusAD: Time-Frequency Fusion with Adaptive Denoising for General Time Series Analysis
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Time series analysis, multi-task learning, adaptive time-frequency fusion, denoising mechanism, masked pre-training

Summary:

1. The paper addresses the challenge of building a unified, efficient, and generalizable framework capable of handling multiple time series tasks such as classification, forecasting, and anomaly detection across diverse data types. 2. Existing methods tend to focus on single tasks or specific time series types, limiting their ability to integrate information across varied datasets and handle noise, complex frequency components, and multi-scale dynamic patterns robustly. 3. The proposed framework, FusAD, introduces an adaptive time-frequency fusion mechanism that combines Fourier and Wavelet transforms to capture both global-local and multi-scale dynamic features effectively. 4. FusAD incorporates an adaptive denoising mechanism that automatically detects and filters different kinds of noise, enhancing the extraction of critical sequence variations in complex environments. 5. The framework includes a general information fusion and decoding structure alongside masked pre-training, facilitating efficient learning and transfer of multi-granularity representations. Experimental results demonstrate that FusAD consistently outperforms state-of-the-art models on standard time series benchmarks while maintaining high efficiency and scalability. The code for FusAD is publicly available for further research and application.
arXiv:2512.14078v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Time series analysis plays a vital role in fields such as finance, healthcare, industry, and meteorology, underpinning key tasks including classification, forecasting, and anomaly detection. Although deep learning models have achieved remarkable progress in these areas in recent years, constructing an efficient, multi-task compatible, and generalizable unified framework for time series analysis remains a significant challenge. Existing approaches are often tailored to single tasks or specific data types, making it difficult to simultaneously handle multi-task modeling and effectively integrate information across diverse time series types. Moreover, real-world data are often affected by noise, complex frequency components, and multi-scale dynamic patterns, which further complicate robust feature extraction and analysis. To ameliorate these challenges, we propose FusAD, a unified analysis framework designed for diverse time series tasks. FusAD features an adaptive time-frequency fusion mechanism, integrating both Fourier and Wavelet transforms to efficiently capture global-local and multi-scale dynamic features. With an adaptive denoising mechanism, FusAD automatically senses and filters various types of noise, highlighting crucial sequence variations and enabling robust feature extraction in complex environments. In addition, the framework integrates a general information fusion and decoding structure, combined with masked pre-training, to promote efficient learning and transfer of multi-granularity representations. Extensive experiments demonstrate that FusAD consistently outperforms state-of-the-art models on mainstream time series benchmarks for classification, forecasting, and anomaly detection tasks, while maintaining high efficiency and scalability. Code is available at https://github.com/zhangda1018/FusAD.

item.title: SonicMoE: Accelerating MoE with IO and Tile-aware Optimizations
item.content:encoded:
Mixture of Experts, Memory-efficient algorithm, GPU kernels, Token rounding, Sparse MoE training

Summary:

1. The paper addresses challenges in fine-grained and sparse Mixture of Experts (MoE) models, which, despite improving model quality per FLOP, face significant activation memory overhead and hardware inefficiencies due to IO costs and padding in Grouped GEMM kernels. 2. The authors propose a novel memory-efficient algorithm that minimizes activation caching during the backward pass of MoEs, reducing activation memory usage by 45%. 3. They design specialized GPU kernels that effectively overlap memory IO with computation, enhancing hardware utilization across various MoE architectures. 4. A new "token rounding" method is introduced to reduce wasted computations caused by padding in Grouped GEMM kernels, leading to better efficiency. 5. Experimental results on Hopper GPUs show that SonicMoE achieves a 1.86x increase in compute throughput compared to ScatterMoE's BF16 kernel on a 7B fine-grained MoE model. On 64 H100 GPUs, SonicMoE attains training throughput of 213 billion tokens/day, comparable to ScatterMoE's 225 billion tokens/day on 96 H100s. 6. Under high sparsity, the tile-aware token rounding method yields an additional 1.16x speedup over vanilla top-K routing without compromising downstream performance. 7. All developed GPU kernels are open-sourced to facilitate faster and more memory-efficient MoE model training.
arXiv:2512.14080v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Mixture of Experts (MoE) models have emerged as the de facto architecture for scaling up language models without significantly increasing the computational cost. Recent MoE models demonstrate a clear trend towards high expert granularity (smaller expert intermediate dimension) and higher sparsity (constant number of activated experts with higher number of total experts), which improve model quality per FLOP. However, fine-grained MoEs suffer from increased activation memory footprint and reduced hardware efficiency due to higher IO costs, while sparser MoEs suffer from wasted computations due to padding in Grouped GEMM kernels. In response, we propose a memory-efficient algorithm to compute the forward and backward passes of MoEs with minimal activation caching for the backward pass. We also design GPU kernels that overlap memory IO with computation benefiting all MoE architectures. Finally, we propose a novel "token rounding" method that minimizes the wasted compute due to padding in Grouped GEMM kernels. As a result, our method SonicMoE reduces activation memory by 45% and achieves a 1.86x compute throughput improvement on Hopper GPUs compared to ScatterMoE's BF16 MoE kernel for a fine-grained 7B MoE. Concretely, SonicMoE on 64 H100s achieves a training throughput of 213 billion tokens per day comparable to ScatterMoE's 225 billion tokens per day on 96 H100s for a 7B MoE model training with FSDP-2 using the lm-engine codebase. Under high MoE sparsity settings, our tile-aware token rounding algorithm yields an additional 1.16x speedup on kernel execution time compared to vanilla top-$K$ routing while maintaining similar downstream performance. We open-source all our kernels to enable faster MoE model training.

item.title: Derivative-Informed Fourier Neural Operator: Universal Approximation and Applications to PDE-Constrained Optimization
item.content:encoded:
Fourier neural operators, Fréchet derivatives, PDE-constrained optimization, surrogate models, operator learning

Summary:

This article introduces derivative-informed Fourier neural operators (DIFNOs), which extend conventional FNOs by training on both the operator outputs and their Fréchet derivatives, enabling accurate emulation of operator responses and sensitivities. The authors motivate DIFNOs by emphasizing the necessity of precise surrogate derivatives for effective PDE-constrained optimization. They establish rigorous approximation theorems demonstrating that FNOs can universally approximate both operators and their Fréchet derivatives on compact sets, and can also approximate operators in weighted Sobolev spaces with unbounded input supports. These theoretical guarantees affirm FNOs’ ability to perform accurate derivative-informed operator learning and solve PDE-constrained optimization problems reliably. To enhance practical applicability, the paper develops efficient training strategies incorporating dimension reduction and multi-resolution techniques, significantly reducing memory and computational demands for derivative learning. Finally, numerical experiments on nonlinear diffusion–reaction, Helmholtz, and Navier–Stokes equations showcase DIFNOs’ superior efficiency and accuracy in learning operators and solving infinite-dimensional PDE-constrained inverse problems, particularly requiring fewer training samples compared to traditional approaches, thus highlighting their potential for scalable and effective surrogate modeling in scientific computing.
arXiv:2512.14086v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We present approximation theories and efficient training methods for derivative-informed Fourier neural operators (DIFNOs) with applications to PDE-constrained optimization. A DIFNO is an FNO trained by minimizing its prediction error jointly on output and Fr\'echet derivative samples of a high-fidelity operator (e.g., a parametric PDE solution operator). As a result, a DIFNO can closely emulate not only the high-fidelity operator's response but also its sensitivities. To motivate the use of DIFNOs instead of conventional FNOs as surrogate models, we show that accurate surrogate-driven PDE-constrained optimization requires accurate surrogate Fr\'echet derivatives. Then, for continuously differentiable operators, we establish (i) simultaneous universal approximation of FNOs and their Fr\'echet derivatives on compact sets, and (ii) universal approximation of FNOs in weighted Sobolev spaces with input measures that have unbounded supports. Our theoretical results certify the capability of FNOs for accurate derivative-informed operator learning and accurate solution of PDE-constrained optimization. Furthermore, we develop efficient training schemes using dimension reduction and multi-resolution techniques that significantly reduce memory and computational costs for Fr\'echet derivative learning. Numerical examples on nonlinear diffusion--reaction, Helmholtz, and Navier--Stokes equations demonstrate that DIFNOs are superior in sample complexity for operator learning and solving infinite-dimensional PDE-constrained inverse problems, achieving high accuracy at low training sample sizes.

item.title: Arithmetic-Intensity-Aware Quantization
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Arithmetic-Intensity-Aware Quantization, mixed precision, post-training quantization, neural network inference, DRAM bandwidth

Summary:
1. The paper addresses the challenge in modern neural networks where inference throughput is constrained by DRAM bandwidth instead of compute capacity, highlighting a memory-bound scenario.
2. It proposes Arithmetic-Intensity-Aware Quantization (AIQ), a novel mixed precision quantization framework designed to optimize per-layer bit-widths to maximize the arithmetic intensity (AI) of neural network inference.
3. AIQ is a post-training quantization method that employs search algorithms to balance a weighted loss function combining AI maximization and minimal accuracy degradation.
4. Experimental results demonstrate that AIQ increases arithmetic intensity by approximately 50% over a full precision (FP32) baseline in ResNet-20 on the CIFAR-10 dataset while maintaining test accuracy within about one percentage point.
5. On the memory-bound MobileNetV2 architecture, AIQ achieves a 1.66x throughput improvement compared to FP32, again preserving accuracy within one percentage point.
6. An interesting behavior observed is AIQ’s tendency to quantize larger layers more aggressively, which contributes to the optimization of overall inference efficiency.
7. The method outperforms global uniform quantization schemes in both arithmetic intensity and throughput, illustrating the benefits of layer-wise adaptive precision allocation under memory constraints.
arXiv:2512.14090v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: As modern neural networks become increasingly memory-bound, inference throughput is limited by DRAM bandwidth rather than compute. We present Arithmetic-Intensity-Aware Quantization (AIQ), a mixed precision quantization framework that chooses per-layer bit-widths to maximize arithmetic intensity (AI) while minimizing accuracy loss. AIQ is a post-training quantization method that uses search algorithms over per-layer quantization schemes to minimize a weighted loss over AI and accuracy. On ResNet-20/CIFAR-10, AIQ increases AI by ~50% over an FP32 baseline while keeping test accuracy within ~1 percentage point, and outperforming global uniform quantization schemes. On a memory-bound MobileNetV2 architecture, AIQ configurations give a 1.66x higher throughput than the FP32 baseline while keeping test accuracy within 1 percentage point. We also find that AIQ naturally quantizes larger layers more aggressively.

item.title: Cornserve: Efficiently Serving Any-to-Any Multimodal Models
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Cornserve, Any-to-Any models, multimodal, model serving, throughput improvement

Summary: The paper introduces Cornserve, an efficient online serving system designed specifically for Any-to-Any multimodal models that accept and generate various combinations of text, images, video, and audio. These models introduce heterogeneity in request types, computation paths, and computational scaling, presenting challenges for efficient serving. Cornserve enables developers to describe the computation graph of these heterogeneous models, which may include components such as multimodal encoders, Large Language Models (LLMs), and multimodal generators like Diffusion Transformers (DiTs). Using this description, Cornserve's planner automatically optimizes the deployment plan, determining whether and how to disaggregate the model into smaller components based on both model structure and workload characteristics. The system’s distributed runtime efficiently executes the model according to this optimized plan, effectively managing the inherent heterogeneity of Any-to-Any models during online serving. Experimental evaluations demonstrate that Cornserve can serve a diverse range of Any-to-Any models and workloads more efficiently than existing solutions, achieving up to 3.81× improvement in throughput and up to 5.79× reduction in tail latency. This highlights Cornserve’s potential to advance multimodal model serving capabilities in real-world applications.
arXiv:2512.14098v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We present Cornserve, an efficient online serving system for an emerging class of multimodal models called Any-to-Any models. Any-to-Any models accept combinations of text and multimodal data (e.g., image, video, audio) as input and also generate combinations of text and multimodal data as output, introducing request type, computation path, and computation scaling heterogeneity in model serving. Cornserve allows model developers to describe the computation graph of generic Any-to-Any models, which consists of heterogeneous components such as multimodal encoders, autoregressive models like Large Language Models (LLMs), and multimodal generators like Diffusion Transformers (DiTs). Given this, Cornserve's planner automatically finds an optimized deployment plan for the model, including whether and how to disaggregate the model into smaller components based on model and workload characteristics. Cornserve's distributed runtime then executes the model per the plan, efficiently handling Any-to-Any model heterogeneity during online serving. Evaluations show that Cornserve can efficiently serve diverse Any-to-Any models and workloads, delivering up to 3.81$\times$ throughput improvement and up to 5.79$\times$ tail latency reduction over existing solutions.

item.title: A First-Order Logic-Based Alternative to Reward Models in RLHF
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback, logic-similarity-based reward, S-GRPO, model alignment, preference learning

Summary:

This paper addresses the challenge of aligning large language models (LLMs) with human values by improving the reward mechanism in Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback (RLHF). Traditional methods such as Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) depend heavily on reward models that estimate human preferences heuristically, which can limit stability and alignment quality. To overcome these limitations, the authors introduce a novel logic-similarity-based reward mechanism that leverages formal logical consistency rather than heuristic reward estimation to guide LLMs towards human-aligned behaviors. Recognizing that questions can be interpreted from multiple perspectives and that purely logic-based reinforcement learning might risk model collapse, they develop S-GRPO, a supervised variant of the GRPO framework. S-GRPO integrates an additional supervised component and jointly optimizes three objectives during training: generation quality, KL-divergence regularization, and a label-based objective. Experimental results demonstrate that S-GRPO consistently outperforms standard supervised fine-tuning (SFT) in terms of both model performance and robustness. Moreover, S-GRPO extends existing preference learning frameworks including GRPO and DPO, providing a more flexible and task-adaptive approach to alignment training. The authors have made their implementation publicly available for further research and development.
arXiv:2512.14100v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback (RLHF) plays a crucial role in aligning large language models (LLMs) with human values and preferences. However, the quality and stability of the trained reward model largely determine the final alignment performance. Existing approaches such as Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) rely heavily on reward models to guide LLMs toward human-aligned behaviors. In this work, we propose a logic-similarity-based reward mechanism as an alternative to conventional reward modeling. Instead of relying on heuristic reward estimation, our method leverages formal logical consistency to steer model alignment with human preferences. Since real-world questions can be interpreted from multiple perspectives, to ensure that logic-based reinforcement learning does not cause model collapse, we introduce S-GRPO, a supervised variant of the GRPO framework. S-GRPO incorporates an additional supervised component and jointly optimizes the generation term, KL-divergence regularization, and label-based objective during training. Experimental results demonstrate that S-GRPO consistently outperforms standard supervised fine-tuning (SFT) in both performance and robustness. Furthermore, it extends existing preference-learning frameworks such as GRPO and DPO, offering a more flexible and task-adaptive approach to alignment training. Our code is available at https://github.com/ChunjinJiang/sgrpo.

item.title: PathFinder: Advancing Path Loss Prediction for Single-to-Multi-Transmitter Scenario
item.content:encoded:
Radio path loss prediction, multi-transmitter scenarios, environmental modeling, distribution shift, deep learning

Summary:

Radio path loss prediction (RPP) is essential for optimizing modern wireless networks such as 5G and IoT. Existing deep learning methods for RPP face three main challenges: they passively model the environment by ignoring key features including transmitters, focus predominantly on single-transmitter scenarios, and perform poorly when the test environment’s distribution differs from that of training, especially regarding building density and transmitter arrangements. To overcome these limitations, the authors propose PathFinder, a novel architecture that actively models both buildings and transmitters through disentangled feature encoding. PathFinder incorporates Mask-Guided Low-rank Attention mechanisms that enable independent focus on the receiver and building regions, improving environmental awareness. Additionally, a Transmitter-Oriented Mixup training strategy is introduced to enhance model robustness against diverse transmitter setups. To rigorously evaluate performance, the authors create a new benchmark called single-to-multi-transmitter RPP (S2MT-RPP), which tests the model’s ability to generalize from single-transmitter training to multi-transmitter scenarios during testing. Extensive experiments demonstrate that PathFinder considerably outperforms state-of-the-art methods, particularly in realistic multi-transmitter and distribution shift conditions. The authors have made their code and project resources publicly available online to support further research and practical applications in RPP.
arXiv:2512.14150v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Radio path loss prediction (RPP) is critical for optimizing 5G networks and enabling IoT, smart city, and similar applications. However, current deep learning-based RPP methods lack proactive environmental modeling, struggle with realistic multi-transmitter scenarios, and generalize poorly under distribution shifts, particularly when training/testing environments differ in building density or transmitter configurations. This paper identifies three key issues: (1) passive environmental modeling that overlooks transmitters and key environmental features; (2) overemphasis on single-transmitter scenarios despite real-world multi-transmitter prevalence; (3) excessive focus on in-distribution performance while neglecting distribution shift challenges. To address these, we propose PathFinder, a novel architecture that actively models buildings and transmitters via disentangled feature encoding and integrates Mask-Guided Low-rank Attention to independently focus on receiver and building regions. We also introduce a Transmitter-Oriented Mixup strategy for robust training and a new benchmark, single-to-multi-transmitter RPP (S2MT-RPP), tailored to evaluate extrapolation performance (multi-transmitter testing after single-transmitter training). Experimental results show PathFinder outperforms state-of-the-art methods significantly, especially in challenging multi-transmitter scenarios. Our code and project site are available at: https://emorzz1g.github.io/PathFinder/.

item.title: On Improving Deep Active Learning with Formal Verification
item.content:encoded: arXiv:2512.14170v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Deep Active Learning (DAL) aims to reduce labeling costs in neural-network training by prioritizing the most informative unlabeled samples for annotation. Beyond selecting which samples to label, several DAL approaches further enhance data efficiency by augmenting the training set with synthetic inputs that do not require additional manual labeling.
